conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves downward.
Four objects on a wooden surface: an ice cream sundae glass, a small black device, a spherical object, and a cylindrical object with a vertical element.
Each object casts a shadow labeled A, B, C, and D respectively.
The current shadows indicate the light source is positioned somewhere above the scene.
When a light source moves downward, shadows become larger, move outward, and the shadow boundary becomes sharper.
Shadow A will grow larger, move further outward, and become more distinctly visible.
Shadow B will increase in size, extend further outward, and show more detailed edges.
Shadow C will grow significantly larger, become more circular, and move further outward.
Shadow D will grow much larger, the vertical element's shadow will elongate, and extend further away.
All four shadows will increase in size, move outward, show more defined edges, and potentially reveal more detail.
When the light source moves downward, shadows A, B, C, and D will increase in size, move outward, develop sharper boundaries, and maintain their relative positions.
